standard_metadata.standard_description: Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.

question.content: You're out on a camping trip, and you're thinking about the geometry of your tent.  It resembles a triangular prism.      **Which shape does the intersection of the vertical plane with the tent look like?**

images.alt: A triangular prism with a rectangle through it that represents the cross-section. The rectangle is at an angle so that it is parallel to a base of the triangular prism. The rectangle moves through the entire triangular prism showing every possible cross-section. It cross-section includes an equilateral triangle.

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the tent vertically and the direction of the cut is parallel to the front of the tent.
The front of the tent (where the zipper is) has the shape of an equilateral triangle.
The shape of a vertical intersection with the tent is an equilateral triangle.      [[â˜ƒ image 1]]

question.content: The figure below shows a right rectangular prism whose base is a $2 \times 2$ square and whose height is $4$.     **Which shape does the intersection of the vertical plane with the prism look like?**

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the prism vertically so the shape of the slice is the same as the shape of the side of the prism.
Since the side of the prism is a $4 \times 2$ rectangle, the shape of the vertical slice is also a $4 \times 2$ rectangle.
The shape of a vertical intersection with the prism is a rectangle.

question.content: The figure below shows a prism whose base is an equilateral triangle.    **Which shape does the intersection of the horizontal plane with the prism look like?**

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the prism horizontally, so the shape of the slice is the same as the shape of the base of the prism.
Since the base of the prism is an equilateral triangle, the shape of the horizontal slice is also an equilateral triangle.
The shape of a horizontal intersection with the prism is an equilateral triangle.      [[â˜ƒ image 1]]

question.content: The figure below shows a right prism whose base is a $2 \times 2$ square and whose height is $4$.     *Note: Figure not to scale.*  **Which shape does the intersection of the horizontal plane with the prism look like?**

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the prism horizontally, so the shape of the slice is the same as the shape of the base of the prism.
Since the prism's base is a $2 \times 2$ square, the shape of the horizontal slice is also a $2 \times 2$ square.
The shape of a horizontal intersection with the prism is a square.     [[â˜ƒ image 1]]

question.content: The figure below shows a right regular prism whose base is a pentagon.      **Which shape does the intersection of the horizontal plane with the prism look like?**

images.alt: A pentagonal prism with a rectangle through it that represents the cross-section. The rectangle is at an angle so that it is parallel to an base of the pentagonal prism. The rectangle moves through the entire pentagonal prism showing every possible cross-section. It cross-section includes a pentagon.

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the prism horizontally so the shape of the slice is the same as the shape of the base of the prism.
Since the base of the prism is a pentagon, the shape of the horizontal slice is also a pentagon.
The shape of a horizontal intersection with the prism is a pentagon.     [[â˜ƒ image 1]]

question.content: The figure below shows a right pyramid whose base is a square.    *Note: Figure not to scale.*  **Which shape does the intersection of the horizontal plane with the pyramid look like?**

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the pyramid horizontally so the shape of the slice is the same as the shape of the base of the pyramid.
Since the pyramid's base is a square, the shape of the horizontal slice is also a square.
The shape of a horizontal intersection with the pyramid is a square.     [[â˜ƒ image 1]]

question.content: The figure below shows a pyramid with a square base.    **Which shape does the intersection of the vertical plane with the pyramid look like?**

images.alt: pyramid with a square base sliced off center

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the pyramid vertically, but not through the center.
The pyramid looks like a triangle when sliced vertically through its center.  When the pyramid is sliced vertically as shown, it looks like a trapezoid.
The shape of an off-centered vertical intersection with the pyramid is an isosceles trapezoid.

question.content: The figure below shows a pyramid with a square base.    **Which shape does the intersection of the vertical plane with the pyramid look like?**

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the pyramid vertically and passes through the center of the pyramid.  What is the shape of the pyramid when you look at it from the side?
The pyramid looks like a triangle when sliced vertically through its center.
The shape of a vertical intersection  with the center of the pyramid is an isosceles triangle.     [[â˜ƒ image 1]]

question.content: The figure below shows an upside-down pyramid with a square base.    *Note: figure not to scale.*  **Which shape does the intersection of the horizontal plane with the pyramid look like?**

images.alt: inverted pyramid with a square base

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the pyramid horizontally so the shape of the slice is the same as the shape of the base of the pyramid.
Since the pyramid's base is a square, the shape of the horizontal slice is also a square.
The shape of a horizontal intersection with the upside-down pyramid is a square.     [[â˜ƒ image 1]]

question.content: The figure below shows a block of butter.      **Which shape does the intersection of the vertical plane with the block of butter look like?**

images.alt: A block of butter that is in the shape of a rectangular prism with a rectangle through it that represents the cross-section. The rectangle is at an angle so that it is perpendicular to an base of the rectangular prism. The rectangle moves through the entire rectangular prism showing every possible cross-section. It cross-section includes a square.

hints.content: Imagine that the plane slices the solid figure.  The slice cuts through the block of butter vertically and is parallel to the front side of the block of butter. The shape of the slice is the same as the front side of the block of butter.
The block of butter has the shape of a right regular prism and its front side is a square.
The shape of the vertical intersection shown in the figure is a square.

question.content: A vertical slice through a three-dimensional solid produces a two-dimensional shape.     **Which one of the following solids can produce this two-dimensional shape when sliced vertically?**

hints.content: The shape we see in the two-dimensional slice is an equilateral triangle.

Which of the solids in the choices would produce a triangular shape when sliced vertically?   Slicing the right rectangular prism and the cube vertically will produce rectangular shapes, not triangles.  A **horizontal** slice through the upright triangular prism will produce a triangular shape, but the question states that we took a vertical slice. A vertical slice through the upright triangular prism looks like a rectangle, so it is not the correct answer either.
The horizontal triangular prism will produce an equilateral triangle when sliced vertically.

question.content: A vertical slice through a three-dimensional solid produces a two-dimensional shape.     **Which one of the following solids can produce this two-dimensional shape when sliced vertically?**

hints.content: The shape we see in the two-dimensional slice is a rectangle.
Which of the solids in the choices would produce a rectangular shape when sliced vertically?   A vertical slice through the pyramids would produce a shape with sloping sides, not a rectangle.
Only the prism could produce the rectangular shape when sliced vertically.

question.content: A vertical slice through a three-dimensional solid produces a two-dimensional shape.     **Which one of the following solids can produce this two-dimensional shape when sliced vertically?**

hints.content: The shape we see in the two-dimensional slice is a triangle.
Which of the solids in the choices would produce a triangle when sliced vertically?
The three prisms all have vertical sides, so slicing them vertically will not produce a triangular shape.
A vertical slice through the center of the pyramid produces a triangular shape.

question.content: A horizontal slice through a three-dimensional solid produces a two-dimensional shape.     **Which one of the following solids produces this two-dimensional shape when sliced horizontally?**

hints.content: The shape we see in the two-dimensional slice is a triangle. Therefore, the solid which was sliced must have a triangular base.
Which of the solids in the choices has a triangular base?
Only the right prism with a triangular base would produce a triangle when sliced horizontally.

question.content: A horizontal slice through a three-dimensional solid produces a two-dimensional shape.     **Which one of the following solids produces this two-dimensional shape when sliced horizontally?**

hints.content: The shape we see in the two-dimensional slice is a pentagon.
Which of the solids in the choices would produce a pentagonal shape when sliced horizontally?   Which of the solids has a pentagonal base?
The prism with a pentagonal base would produce a pentagonal shape when sliced horizontally.

question.content: A horizontal slice through a three-dimensional solid produces a two-dimensional shape.     **Which one of the following solids produces this two-dimensional shape when sliced horizontally?**

hints.content: The shape we see in the two-dimensional slice is hexagon.
Which of the solids in the choices would produce a hexagonal shape when sliced horizontally?   Which of the solids has a hexagonal base?
The prism with a hexagonal base would produce a hexagon when sliced horizontally.

question.content: A horizontal slice through a three-dimensional solid produces a two-dimensional shape.     **Which one of the following solids produces this two-dimensional shape when sliced horizontally?**

hints.content: The shape we see in the two-dimensional slice is a square.
Which of the solids in the choices would produce a square shape when sliced horizontally?   Which of the solids has a square base?
The prism with a square base would produce a square shape when sliced horizontally.
